entry.title: Meeting with Prof. Maneesh Singhal and his research group

link.title: Meeting with Prof. Maneesh Singhal and his research group

entry.content:
A first meeting took place today between Prof. Maneesh Singhal and his team, and Prof. Dominik Wujastyk and members of the SuÅ›ruta Project group. The international meeting was held using Zoom, with participants in India, the USA and Canada.

The meeting discussed the collaboration between Dominik Wujastykâ€™s team and Maneesh Singhalâ€™s group on the SuÅ›ruta project. Dominikâ€™s team focuses on ancient Sanskrit manuscripts, while Maneeshâ€™s team aims to establish a museum on SuÅ›ruta literature and develop a SuÅ›ruta research group.

The research groups plan to exchange knowledge on surgical instruments, phytochemistry, and historical contexts. Maneeshâ€™s team includes surgeons, biotechnologists, and ayurvedic physicians, and they will work on recreating SuÅ›ruta instruments and studying veterinary medicine. Future meetings will be held to coordinate efforts and share progress.

Present:

AIIMS group: Prof. Maneesh Singhal, Aanchal Sharma, Suttee, Samad, Arjun Ganguly, Manoj Kumar Jha, Shivani Gupta, Nandini Singh Tanwar.

SS Project group: Prof. Dominik Wujastyk, Harshal Bhatt, Jason Birch, Lisa A. Brooks, Madhusudan Rimal, Tyler Neill.

The participants all introduced themselves, giving a thumbnail sketch of their respective interests in the projects.

Prof. Singhal discussed his project on science and heritage research in India, aiming to establish a museum about SuÅ›ruta literature and develop a SuÅ›ruta research group. The museum will include artifacts, reconstructions of ancient surgical instruments, 3D printed materials, paintings, and a movie, funded by the government of India.

Prof. Wujastyk discussed the old Nepalese manuscripts of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ that have given us a window onto what the text looked like in the ninth century, and how it differed from what circulates today. Dr Brooks mentioned, as an example, the fact that the Nepalese version lists 21 surgical instruments while the contemporary printed editions mention only 20.

The meeting concluded with expressions of gratitude and anticipation for future collaborations.

entry.content:
The NyÄyacandrikÄ by GayadÄsa (fl. ca. 1000, Bengal) is one of the important early commentaries on the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ that has largely been lost in the sands of time. I say â€œlargelyâ€ because only a relatively small portion is known to have survived: the commentary on one of SuÅ›rutaâ€™s six books, the NidÄnasthÄna, which was edited and published by Acharya Trivikramji in his 1938 edition of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ (Ä€cÄrya & Ä€cÄrya, 1938).

We know that GayadÄsaâ€™s commentary was important because it was frequently cited by á¸Œalhaá¹‡a, a twelfth-century author whose commentary came to define the version of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ that was printed and widely disseminated in the twentieth century. Since á¸Œalhaá¹‡a often refers to GayadÄsaâ€™s views and records many variant readings known to this earlier commentator, it is clear that GayadÄsa played a significant role in the transmission and interpretation of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ.

Given GayadÄsaâ€™s importance to the history of SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ, the existence of several unpublished manuscripts of the NyÄyacandrikÄ should be a priority for further research on the history of this medical tradition. For this reason, I was delighted to have the opportunity to read and transcribe GayadÄsaâ€™s commentary on the second chapter of SuÅ›rutaâ€™s SÅ«trasthÄna.

My delight soon turned to anguish when I examined the sixteenth century manuscript Bikaner Anup 4389, which is held by the Anup Sanskrit Library in the Lalgarh Palace, Bikaner. The most obvious problem was the frequent lacunae in the text, which the scribe represented with a dash for each syllable that was missing. It appears that the manuscript from which the scribe was copying had already been severely damaged, because several lines of dashes, sometimes numbering up to ten or twelve, appear on every folio. Each lacuna renders sentences, compounds, and words incomplete.

Perhaps even more devastating than the lacunae, however, was the amount of gibberish spread throughout the text. Scholars who work with handwritten manuscripts of texts that have been poorly transmitted expect to encounter mistakes, and if these errors are small, they can usually be corrected so that the text can be understood, if not fully, then at least substantially. For editing purposes, one typically requires two or more manuscripts to correct a range of mistakes with some confidence.

Unfortunately, manuscript Anup 4389 contains mistakes in every sentence, some of which a later hand has attempted to correct. Many letters have been crossed out and replaced with others written in the margin or above the line. These attempted corrections sometimes render the text even more illegible. When combined with the lacunae, the gibberish makes much of the manuscript incomprehensible. The difficulty of reading this manuscript (without another copy for comparison) is particularly evident in passages that correspond to á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary. In such instances, one can be more certain of what GayadÄsa originally wrote and therefore see the manuscriptâ€™s gibberish clearly. For example,

á¸Œalhaá¹‡a: krodhaá¸¥ parasyÄpakÄrapÅ«rvakaá¹ƒ há¹›dayottejaá¸¥
GayadÄsa: kovaá¸¥ parasyatyakÄrapÅ«rvikÄ haravitejaá¸¥

In some cases, the manuscript reading is good enough to make sense of the text when read against á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s parallel comment:

á¸Œalhaá¹‡a: kÄmaá¸¥ viÅ›iá¹£á¹­astrÄ«viá¹£ayasparÅ›asaá¹…kalpaá¸¥, athavÄ Å›abdÄdiá¹£u grahaá¹‡apravá¹›ttirvÄ, svabÄndhavaká¹›tasneho vÄ kÄmaá¸¥ Â 
GayadÄsa: tatra kÄmo vi+á¹£á¹­astriviá¹£ayasparÅ›aá¸¥ prakalpaá¸¥ athavÄ Å›abdÄdiá¹£u grahapratahir vÄ kÄmo diá¹£va grahapravá¹›ttisu vidyÄkÅ«laá¹ƒ Â 

In other cases, however, the text is so corrupt that one cannot be certain that the passages are parallel:

á¸Œalhaá¹‡a: lobhaá¸¥ parasvagrahaá¹‡ecchÄ;
GayadÄsa: lÄtetharadhagrahÄ

I did not record the number of parallel passages between GayadÄsa and á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s commentaries in the section I transcribed (and it would likely be more productive to do so with sections of the NidÄnasthÄna) but I was left with the impression that at least 20% of GayadÄsaâ€™s commentary was close to á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s. This suggests that á¸Œalhaá¹‡a tacitly borrowed material from GayadÄsa, in addition to the passages he explicitly attributed to him. In certain places, GayadÄsaâ€™s commentary is more extensive, and á¸Œalhaá¹‡a seems to be summarising it. And in other places, á¸Œalhaá¹‡a expands on it.

Although manuscript Anup 4389 is unlikely to ever serve as the sole basis for a critical edition and translation, it may be possible (albeit frustrating) to use it to identify parallels with á¸Œalhaá¹‡a. Such parallels may help to elucidate the extent to which this later commentator, whose work may appear largely original, was in fact redacting material from his predecessors.

New project publication

We are pleased to announce a new project publication from Dr Lisa A. Brooks:

  1. â€œâ€˜On Leechesâ€™ in a Medical Treatise for Humans: The Nepalese Version of SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ 1.13â€. History of Science in South Asia 14 (January):1-42. https://doi.org/10.18732/hssa122.

Abstract

Humans and leeches have engaged in human medicine together for at least two thousand years. Perhaps the earliest detailed description of this interaction is found in a chapter on leech therapy from an early first-millennium Sanskrit surgical treatise, the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ. There we find descriptions of how humans should classify, care for, interpret, and interact with leeches in medical practice. This article contributes to our understanding of leech therapy in South Asia broadly and to the textual history of this important medical treatise through a comparative study of a newly generated â€œNepalese versionâ€ of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄâ€™s chapter â€œOn Leechesâ€ together with the most widely cited version (Ä€chÄrya 1938) that was published with á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s twelfth-century commentary. The final portion of the article presents an edition and translation of the Nepalese version of the chapter â€œOn Leechesâ€ prepared by the author along with members of the SuÅ›ruta Project. The edition is based on three Nepalese manuscripts, including a palm leaf manuscript dating from 878 C.E., one of the earliest extant Sanskrit palm-leaf manuscripts of any genre.

entry.content:
Introduction (Dominik Wujastyk)

The following post illustrates the creative philological process that can lead to an emendation to a text in spite of the transmitted readings of the manuscript witnesses.

During an online reading seminar, we were puzzled by the Nepalese manuscript readings of passage SS 3.1.3. In the vulgate version, the passage reads (Ä€cÄrya & Ä€cÄrya, 1938, p. 338):

tad ekam anekeá¹£Äá¹ƒ ká¹£etrajÃ±ÄnÄm adhiá¹£á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ samudra ivaudakanÄá¹ƒ bhÄvÄnÄm Â 

That One is the foundation of the many Witnesses, just like the ocean for aquatic (audaka) beings.

The Nepalese witnesses N and H both read ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ â€œfor beings who have water as their energy (ojas).â€ This is an unusual use of the word ojas and the meaning of the simile is not clear.

Philipp Maas, project collaborator (ORCID), was able to suggest a compelling solution to this conundrum.

Reflections (Philipp Maas)

Following our online meeting, the illustration in ÅšÄ 1.3 continued to puzzle me. Even if the phrase tad ekam anekeá¹£Äá¹ƒ ká¹£etrajÃ±ÄnÄm adhiá¹£á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ samudra ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ bhÄvÄnÄm makes some sense, it is hardly correct because the technical term -ojas as a final part of a bahuvrÄ«hi compound does not fit the context. It remains unclear what kind of entities or beings could be described as â€œhaving water as their powerâ€ and how such a characterisation can be understood in a comparison (which should be clear without specialist knowledge) of the role of avyakta for the ká¹£etrejÃ±as.

In this situation, an editor could either mark the edited text as corrupt or suggest an emendation. However, my suggestion to read ivodakajÄnÄá¹ƒ instead of ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ was unsatisfactory because there is no reason why the unobjectionable and easy reading ivodakajÄnÄá¹ƒ could be changed in the course of the transmission into the more difficult but apparently incorrect ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ in the Nepalese version. I have now found a better solution to this problem and propose a different emendation, namely to emend udakaujasÄá¹ƒ to udakaukasÄá¹ƒ â€œhaving water as their house or habitat, living in water, aquatic,â€ which involves the change of the single aká¹£ara ja to ka, making okas out of ojas.

Admittedly, I have not yet been able to detect an occurrence of the word udakaukas in Sanskrit literature, but jalaukas is quite common, meaning â€œleechâ€ or â€œaquatic beingâ€ as, for example, in MBh 12.195.22: Å›ubhÄÅ›ubhaá¹ƒ karma ká¹›taá¹ƒ yad asya tad eva pratyÄdadate svadehe / mano â€˜nuvartanti parÄvarÄá¹‡i jalaukasaá¸¥ srota ivÄnukÅ«lam // (22.2). Since jalaukas is a substantivised adjective, nothing prevents the usage of the parallel formation udakaukas as a bahuvrÄ«hi meaning â€œaquatic.â€

The passage

tad ekam anekeá¹£Äá¹ƒ ká¹£etrajÃ±ÄnÄm adhiá¹£á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ samudra ivodakaukasÄá¹ƒ bhÄvÄnÄm Â 

would then translate as

Some of these may indeed be concrete evidence for a commentary on the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ by Jejjaá¹­a. They need to be studied individually, especially those of á¸Œalhaá¹‡a and NiÅ›calakara.

Induâ€™s commentary on the Aá¹£á¹­Äá¹…gasaá¹…graha

But, â€¦ he filled up a lacuna in the ÅšaÅ›ilekhÄ with the text of the NirantarapadÄ« commentary (on SuÅ›ruta) by Jarjaá¹­a (vol. The passage on p. 298 of RudrapÄraÅ›araâ€™s edition reads as follows:

One has to ask, â€œwhose voice is this commentarial statement?â€ It is impossible that Indu (fl. ca. 1000â€“1150) would have referred to his own commentary by name, saying that it was incomplete. It is also unlikely that it was RudrapÄraÅ›ara, in the 1920s. The passage is printed in the same size and font as the rest of the text of the ÅšaÅ›ilekhÄ.
